data.title: At Sundance, a Lot of James Franco and Other Experiments
data.meta_description: The Sundance Film Festival unveiled two more sections that will be part of its 2013 edition, and films involving James Franco are a recurring theme.
data.text:
LOS ANGELES – James Franco’s next big movie is the Disney extravaganza “Oz: The Great and Powerful,” due March 8, and the Mouseketeers have been working hard to establish him in marketing materials as a family-friendly leading man.

Sundance apparently didn’t get the memo. Festival programmers on Thursday unveiled another section of their lineup – drip, drip, drip – and Mr. Franco explores sadomasochistic sex in two films.

The actor-filmmaker tackles the gay variety in “Interior. Leather Bar.” To avoid an X rating, it was rumored that 40 minutes were cut from the 1980 film “Cruising,” and Mr. Franco’s film sets out to reimagine what was lost. “Kink” is a documentary, produced by Mr. Franco and directed by Christina Voros, that looks at “the sprawling porn production facilities of Kink.com.”

Sundance is slated to announce films in its high-profile Premieres section on Monday. If “Lovelace,” a drama about the porn star Linda Lovelace, makes the cut, Mr. Franco, who plays Hugh Hefner in that film, will have three sex-themed movies in Park City in January.

“Interior. Leather Bar” and “Kink” are selections in Sundance’s experimental New Frontier and racy Midnight programs. Other notable entries include GJ Echternkamp’s “Virtually Heroes,” about characters in a “Call of Duty”-style video game; two horror movies that explore country roads and small towns – “In Fear” and “The Rambler”; and “Charlie Victor Romeo” a documentary in which actors act out black box recordings of planes that have crashed.

Below are Sundance’s full 2013 Midnight and New Frontier programs, along with the lineup for Spotlight, a section devoted to movies that have already played other festivals:

PARK CITY AT MIDNIGHT

Ass Backwards (Director: Chris Nelson, Screenwriters: June Diane Raphael, Casey Wilson) — Loveable losers Kate and Chloe take a road trip back to their hometown to claim the beauty-pageant crown that eluded them as children, only to discover what really counts: friendship.

Hell Baby (Directors and screenwriters: Robert Ben Garant, Thomas Lennon) — An expectant couple moves into the most haunted fixer-upper in New Orleans, a house with a demonic curse. Things spiral out of control and soon only the Vatican’s elite exorcism team can save the pair – or can it?

In Fear (Directed and story by: Jeremy Lovering) — Trapped in a maze of country roads with only their vehicle for protection, Tom and Lucy are terrorized by an unseen tormentor exploiting their worst fears. Eventually they realize they’ve let the evil in – it’s sitting in their car.

Kink (Director: Christina Voros) — A documentary about sex, submission and big business is told through the eyes of the unlikely pornographers whose 9-to-5 workdays are spent within the confines of the San Francisco Armory building, home to the sprawling porn production facilities of Kink.com.

The Rambler (Director and screenwriter: Calvin Lee Reeder) — After being released from prison, a man known as “The Rambler” stumbles upon a strange mystery as he attempts the treacherous journey through back roads and small towns en route to reconnecting with his long-lost brother.

S-VHS (Directors: Simon Barrett, Adam Wingard, Edúardo Sanchez, Gregg Hale, Timo Tjahjanto, Gareth Huw Evans, Jason Eisener, Screenwriters: Simon Barrett, Jamie Nash, Timo Tjahjanto & Gareth Huw Evans, John Davies) — Searching for a missing student, two private investigators break into his abandoned house and find another collection of mysterious VHS tapes. In viewing the horrific contents of each cassette, they realize there may be terrifying motives behind the student’s disappearance.

Virtually Heroes (Director: GJ Echternkamp, Screenwriter: Matt Yamashita) — Two self-aware characters in a “Call of Duty”-style video game struggle with their screwy, frustrating existence. To find answers, one abandons his partner and mission, seeking to unravel the cheat codes of life.

We Are What We Are (Director: Jim Mickle, Screenwriters: Nick Damici, Jim Mickle) — A devastating storm washes up clues that lead authorities closer and closer to the cannibalistic Parker family.

NEW FRONTIER

Charlie Victor Romeo (Directors: Robert Berger, Karlyn Michelson, Screenwriters: Robert Berger, Patrick Daniels, Irving Gregory) — An award-winning theatrical documentary derived entirely from “black box” transcripts of six real-life major airline emergencies brought to the screen with cutting-edge stereoscopic 3D technology.

Fat Shaker (Director and screenwriter: M Shirvani) — An obese father and his handsome deaf son share extraordinary experiences in Tehran. Then a beautiful young woman upsets the balance of their relationship, forcing them to renegotiate their position with each other and the world around them.

Interior. Leather Bar. (Directors: Travis Mathews, James Franco, Screenwriter: Travis Mathews) — To avoid an X rating, it was rumored that 40 minutes of footage involving gay sadomasochism was cut from the controversial 1980 film, Cruising. The filmmakers reimagine what was lost.

Halley (Director: Sebastian Hofmann, Screenwriters: Sebastian Hofmann, Julio Chavezmontes) — Alberto is dead and can no longer hide it. Before surrendering to his living death, he forms an unusual friendship with Luly, the manager of the 24-hour gym where he works as a night guard.

The Meteor (Director: François Delisle, Screenwriter: François Delisle) — Forty-something Pierre, his mother and his wife are linked by crime, guilt and loneliness. Like casualties of love and desire, they are dying to stick their heads above water and breathe the air of life.

SPOTLIGHT

Fill the Void (Director and screenwriter: Rama Burshtein) — A devout 18-year-old Israeli is pressured to marry the husband of her late sister. Declaring her independence is not an option in Tel Aviv’s ultra-Orthodox Hasidic community, where religious law, tradition and the rabbi’s word are absolute.

Gangs of Wasseypur (Director: Anurag Kashyap, Screenwriters: Anurag Kashyap, Zeishan Quadri) — Exiled and outcast for robbing British trains, Shahid Khan spurs a battle for revenge that passes down generations. Shahid’s son vows to get his father’s honor back, becoming the most feared man in the Indian town of Wasseypur.

The Gatekeepers (Director: Dror Moreh) — Since its military victory in 1967, Israel has hoped to achieve a long-lasting peace. Forty-five years later, this has yet to happen. Six former heads of Israel’s Secret Service reflect on the successes and failures of the “peace process” in this documentary

Mud (Director and screenwriter: Jeff Nichols) — Two teenage boys encounter a fugitive and form a pact to help him evade the bounty hunters on his trail and reunite him with his true love.

No (Director: Pablo Larraín, Screenwriter: Pedro Peirano) — When Chilean military dictator Augusto Pinochet calls for a referendum to decide his permanence in power, the opposition persuades a young advertising executive to head its campaign. With limited resources and under scrutiny, he conceives a plan to win the election.

Sightseers (Director: Ben Wheatley, Screenwriters: Alice Lowe, Steve Oram) — Chris wants to show girlfriend Tina his world, but when events conspire against the couple, their dream caravan holiday takes a very wrong turn.
